title: New Directions in Learning and Skills in England, Scotland and Wales: Recent Policy and Future Possibilities.
abstractText:
This Project built on earlier ESRC Teaching and Learning Research Programme (TLRP) activity and theoretical developments by exploring approaches to learning and skills and lifelong learning policy in England, Scotland and Wales and identifying themes for future research, policy and practice.

The specific aims of the Project, which were explored through five research-based seminars, involving policy-makers, practitioners and researchers from the three countries were:

  1. To help those working within the learning and skills sector to understand recent developments and their implications for learners, professionals, policy-makers and researchers across the three countries.
  2. To focus on the changing balance between local, regional and national relationships.
  3. To bring different theoretical perspectives (e.g. ‘policy mediation’, ‘learning cultures’, ‘devolved social partnership’) to bear on current directions in learning and skills to aid reflection and policy learning.
  4. To identify areas of convergence and divergence concerning the future direction of learning and skills in the three countries.
  5. To build a cross-UK network of expertise in this area.

The findings, which suggested increasing divergence across the UK, are written up in Post-compulsory education and lifelong learning across the UK: policy, organisation and governance, edited by Ann Hodgson, Ken Spours and Martyn Waring (IOE Publications, 2011).
